When working with data with missing values (aka NA orÂ *not available*), we have to be careful about the operations we do. In this short article, we will look at different NA data types that someone may deal with when working with Pandas or NumPy libraries.

There are different null objects such asÂ **numpy.nan/numpy.NaN**Â (Not a Number),Â **pandas.NaT**Â (Not a Time), or pythonâ€™sÂ **None**Â type object. Null objects may behave unexpectedly and result in aÂ [semantic error](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_error)Â (aka logic error) that is not easy to find or debug. UnlikeÂ [syntax errors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_error), your program will compile successfully even if there are semantic errors.

### **Comparing Null Objects (==Â vs.Â is )**

When comparing a Python object that may be NA, keep in mind the difference between the two Pythonâ€™s equality operators: â€œ***is***â€and â€œ***==***â€. Pythonâ€™s keyword â€œ***is***â€ compares theÂ *identities*Â of two variables*,*Â while â€œ***==***â€ compares two variables by checking whether they are equal. Letâ€™s see how these two differ.

```python
None == None
# >>> True

None is None
# >>> True
```

When comparing Pythonâ€™s **None** object, both â€œ**==**â€ and â€œ**is**â€ yield the same results. However, the output is different when **numpy.nan** null object is used!

```python
numpy.nan == numpy.nan
# >>> False

numpy.nan is numpy.nan
# >>> True
```

This behavior may result in a semantic error, particularly if we do an element-wise comparison. For example, assume that we have

```python
data = [1.0, np.nan, 2.0]
```

And we want to print a message on whether there is a missing value in the **data** or not.

```python
# Using "==" in the element-wise comparison
for x in data:
    if x == np.nan:
        print(f"Using '==' -->  {x} is a nan!")
    else:
        print(f"Using '==' -->  {x} is not a nan!")

# Using "is" in the element-wise comparison
for x in data:
    if x is np.nan:
        print(f"Using 'is' -->  {x} is a nan!")
    else:
        print(f"Using 'is' -->  {x} is not a nan!")
```

```python
Using '==' -->  1.0 is not a nan!
Using '==' -->  nan is not a nan!
Using '==' -->  2.0 is not a nan!
Using 'is' -->  1.0 is not a nan!
Using 'is' -->  nan is a nan!
Using 'is' -->  2.0 is not a nan!
```

It is safer to use Pandas and/or NumPyâ€™s built-in methods to check for missing values. We will cover this in the next section.

# **Finding null objects in Pandas & NumPy**

It is always safer to use NumPy or Pandas built-in methods to check for NAs. In NumPy, we can check for NaN entries by usingÂ *[numpy.isnan()](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.isnan.html)*Â method. NumPy only supports its NaN objects and throws an error if we pass other null objects to numpy.*isnan()*.

```python
numpy.isnan(np.nan)
# >>> True

numpy.isnan(None)
# >>> TypeError
```

I suggest you use *pandas.isna()* or its alias *pandas.isnull()* as they are more versatile than *numpy.isnan()* and accept other data objects and not only *numpy.nan*.

```python
# pandas.isna() is an alias of pandas.isnull()
pandas.isna(np.nan)
# >>> True

pandas.isna(None)
# >>> True

pandas.isna(pd.NaT)
# >>> True
```

# **Calculations with missing data**

Let me tell you a story that happened to me a few days ago. I wanted to calculate the Median Absolute Deviation usingÂ *[mad()](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.robust.scale.mad.html)*Â from theÂ *[statsmodel](https://www.statsmodels.org/)*Â library that is dependent on theÂ *median()*Â function from NumPy. I had NaN entries in the data I was working on, and consequently, the output result was NaN since there was at least one missing value in the input array. It took me some time to find this semantic error. So, I figured the following out in a hard way:

<aside>
âš ï¸ Missing values propagate through arithmetic operations in NumPy and Pandas unless they are dropped or filled with a value.

</aside>

The following examples illustrate what happens when we calculate some statistics from our data without considering the missing values:

```python
2 + numpy.nan
# >>> nan

numpy.nan / 2
# >>> nan
```

You have to be cautious about NaNs in your data when you are calculating any statistic. For example, letâ€™s calculate the mean of an array including a NaN.

```python
numpy.mean([1.0, 2.0, 3.0, numpy.NaN])
# >>> nan

numpy.nanmean([1.0, 2.0, 3.0, numpy.NaN])
# >>> 2.0
```

NumPy functions that calculate data statistics usually have counterpart functions to work with NaNs such as [numpy.nansum()](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.nansum.html) and [numpy.nanstd()](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.nanstd.html).

# **Recommendations**

- Always keep in mind the difference between equality operators â€œ***==***â€ and â€œ***is***â€.
- UseÂ *Pandas*Â built-in methods to check for NA entries.
- Pay attention to the behavior of functions in the presence of null objects, particularly functions to calculate statistical properties.
